# Part 1: The `if` Statement

## What is a Conditional Statement?

::: {style="text-align:center; margin-top: 30px;"}
### A **conditional statement** tells Python: *"Only do this if something is true"* {style="color: #2980b9; font-size: 1.4em;"}
:::

**Real-life examples of conditions:**

- **If** it is raining ‚Üí bring an umbrella
- **If** the score is above 50 ‚Üí you pass
- **If** the password is correct ‚Üí allow login

```python
# Without conditions, ALL code always runs
print("Hello!")         # This always runs

# With conditions, code runs ONLY when True
age = 20
if age >= 18:
    print("You are an adult.")   # Only runs if age >= 18
```

::: {.callout-note}
## üí° Key Idea
Conditional statements let your program respond differently to different situations.
:::

## Syntax of the `if` Statement

**The structure of an `if` statement:**

```python
if condition:
    # code to run when condition is True
    # this block is INDENTED (4 spaces or 1 tab)
```

**Rules to remember:**

- The condition is followed by a **colon** `:`
- The code inside must be **indented** (press Tab or 4 spaces)
- Indented code is called the **body** or **block**

```python
temperature = 35

if temperature > 30:
    print("It is hot today!")
    print("Stay hydrated.")

print("This always runs.")   # Not indented = outside the if
```

::: {.callout-warning}
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Indentation is REQUIRED
Python uses indentation to know what belongs inside the `if`. Missing or wrong indentation causes an error!
:::

## Indentation: The Most Important Rule

```python
# ‚úÖ CORRECT ‚Äî indented with 4 spaces
score = 85
if score >= 50:
    print("You passed!")   # 4 spaces before print

# ‚ùå WRONG ‚Äî no indentation ‚Üí IndentationError
if score >= 50:
print("You passed!")       # ERROR! Must be indented

# ‚ùå WRONG ‚Äî inconsistent indentation
if score >= 50:
  print("You passed!")     # 2 spaces
    print("Great job!")    # 4 spaces ‚Üí ERROR!
```

::: {.callout-important}
## üéØ Golden Rule
**Everything inside an `if` block must have the SAME indentation level.**
Use 4 spaces consistently (or Tab ‚Äî but not both).
:::

## How Python Evaluates the Condition

Python checks if the condition is `True` or `False`:

```python
x = 10

# Condition is True ‚Üí block RUNS
if x > 5:
    print("x is greater than 5")    # ‚úÖ This runs

# Condition is False ‚Üí block is SKIPPED
if x > 20:
    print("x is greater than 20")   # ‚ùå This is skipped

print("Done.")   # Always runs
```

**Step-by-step thinking:**

```
x = 10
Is x > 5?  ‚Üí  Is 10 > 5?  ‚Üí  True  ‚Üí  Run the block ‚úÖ
Is x > 20? ‚Üí  Is 10 > 20? ‚Üí  False ‚Üí  Skip the block ‚ùå
```

::: {.callout-tip}
## üí° Think like Python
Always ask: "Is this condition True or False right now?"
:::

## Multiple Statements in an `if` Block

You can put multiple lines inside one `if`:

```python
score = 92

if score >= 90:
    print("Grade: A")
    print("Excellent work!")
    print("You are in the top class.")

# All three lines only run if score >= 90
```

**Another example:**

```python
balance = 500
withdrawal = 200

if withdrawal <= balance:
    balance = balance - withdrawal
    print("Withdrawal successful!")
    print(f"New balance: ${balance}")

print("Thank you for using our ATM.")
```

::: {.callout-note}
## üìå Remember
All lines at the same indentation level belong to the same block.
:::

# Part 2: The `else` Statement

## What is `else`?

::: {style="text-align:center; margin-top: 30px;"}
### `else` runs when the `if` condition is **False** {style="color: #2980b9; font-size: 1.4em;"}

It is the "otherwise" option.
:::

**Real-life thinking:**

- If it is raining ‚Üí bring umbrella. **Otherwise** ‚Üí wear sunglasses.
- If score >= 50 ‚Üí you pass. **Otherwise** ‚Üí you fail.
- If username is correct ‚Üí log in. **Otherwise** ‚Üí show error.

```python
score = 45

if score >= 50:
    print("You passed!")
else:
    print("You failed. Please try again.")
```

::: {.callout-important}
## üéØ Key Point
Either the `if` block runs, OR the `else` block runs. **Never both. Never neither.**
:::

## Syntax of `if...else`

```python
if condition:
    # runs when condition is True
    code_block_A
else:
    # runs when condition is False
    code_block_B
```

**Important rules:**

- `else` has NO condition ‚Äî it is the "everything else" case
- `else` must be at the same indentation as `if`
- `else` also ends with a **colon** `:`
- The body of `else` must be indented

```python
temperature = 22

if temperature > 30:
    print("It is hot!")
else:
    print("The weather is comfortable.")
```

::: {.callout-tip}
## üí° Think of it as a fork in the road
`if` takes the left path, `else` takes the right path. You always take one.
:::

## Visualizing if...else Flow

```
         Start
           ‚îÇ
           ‚ñº
     [Check condition]
           ‚îÇ
     ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¥‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
   True         False
     ‚îÇ             ‚îÇ
     ‚ñº             ‚ñº
  [if block]   [else block]
     ‚îÇ             ‚îÇ
     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¨‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
           ‚îÇ
           ‚ñº
     Continue...
```

```python
password = "hello123"

if password == "secret":
    print("Access granted!")
else:
    print("Wrong password. Access denied.")

print("Program ended.")   # Always runs after
```

## Multiple Lines in if...else

Both blocks can have multiple statements:

```python
marks = 72

if marks >= 50:
    print("Result: PASS ‚úÖ")
    print(f"Your score: {marks}/100")
    print("Congratulations! You may proceed.")
else:
    print("Result: FAIL ‚ùå")
    print(f"Your score: {marks}/100")
    print("You need to retake the exam.")

print("---")
print("End of result.")
```

::: {.callout-note}
## üìå Both branches can have different amounts of code
The `if` block can have 1 line, the `else` block can have 5 lines ‚Äî or vice versa.
:::

# Part 3: The `elif` Statement

## The Problem with Only if...else

What if there are **more than two** possible outcomes?

```python
score = 75

# ‚ùå This approach is messy and incorrect logic
if score >= 90:
    print("Grade: A")
if score >= 80:
    print("Grade: B")   # 75 doesn't match, but 90+ would print BOTH A and B!
if score >= 70:
    print("Grade: C")
```

::: {.callout-warning}
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Problem
Using multiple separate `if` statements means ALL conditions are checked independently. A score of 95 would print A, B, AND C ‚Äî that's wrong!
:::

**Solution:** Use `elif` to create a **chain** of conditions.

## What is `elif`?

::: {style="text-align:center; margin-top: 30px;"}
### `elif` = "else if" ‚Äî check another condition only if the previous was False {style="color: #2980b9; font-size: 1.4em;"}
:::

```python
if condition1:
    # runs if condition1 is True
elif condition2:
    # runs if condition1 is False AND condition2 is True
elif condition3:
    # runs if condition1 and condition2 are False AND condition3 is True
else:
    # runs if ALL conditions above are False
```

::: {.callout-important}
## üéØ Key Rule
Python checks conditions **top to bottom** and **stops at the first True one**.
Only ONE block ever runs.
:::

## Syntax: if...elif...else

```python
score = 75

if score >= 90:
    print("Grade: A")
elif score >= 80:
    print("Grade: B")
elif score >= 70:
    print("Grade: C")
elif score >= 60:
    print("Grade: D")
else:
    print("Grade: F")

# Output: Grade: C
```

**Step-by-step trace:**

```
Is score >= 90? ‚Üí Is 75 >= 90? ‚Üí False ‚Üí skip
Is score >= 80? ‚Üí Is 75 >= 80? ‚Üí False ‚Üí skip
Is score >= 70? ‚Üí Is 75 >= 70? ‚Üí True  ‚Üí Print "Grade: C" ‚úÖ STOP
```

## Visualizing elif Flow

```
         Start
           ‚îÇ
           ‚ñº
     [condition1?]
           ‚îÇ
     ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¥‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
   True         False
     ‚îÇ             ‚îÇ
     ‚ñº             ‚ñº
  [block1]   [condition2?]
     ‚îÇ         ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¥‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
     ‚îÇ       True   False
     ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ       ‚îÇ
     ‚îÇ      [block2] [condition3?]
     ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ      ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¥‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
     ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ    True   False
     ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ      ‚îÇ       ‚îÇ
     ‚îÇ         ‚îÇ  [block3]  [else]
     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¨‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò      ‚îÇ       ‚îÇ
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¥‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
                      ‚îÇ
                      ‚ñº
                  Continue...
```

## How Order Matters in elif

The **order** of your conditions is critical!

```python
score = 95

# ‚úÖ CORRECT ORDER ‚Äî most restrictive first
if score >= 90:
    print("A")       # 95 >= 90 ‚Üí True ‚Üí prints A, stops here ‚úÖ
elif score >= 80:
    print("B")
elif score >= 70:
    print("C")

# ‚ùå WRONG ORDER ‚Äî least restrictive first
if score >= 70:
    print("C")       # 95 >= 70 ‚Üí True ‚Üí prints C! Wrong! ‚ùå
elif score >= 80:
    print("B")       # Never reached for score 95
elif score >= 90:
    print("A")       # Never reached for score 95
```

::: {.callout-warning}
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Always order from MOST specific to LEAST specific
For ranges: put the highest threshold first (or lowest, depending on direction).
:::

## elif Without else

`else` is **optional**. You can have `if...elif` without a final `else`:

```python
day = "Saturday"

if day == "Saturday":
    print("Weekend! Sleep in. üò¥")
elif day == "Sunday":
    print("Weekend! Relax. ‚òÄÔ∏è")

# If day is Monday-Friday: nothing prints
print("Have a good day!")
```

::: {.callout-note}
## üí° When to skip `else`
Skip `else` when it is acceptable to do nothing if no condition matches.
Include `else` when you need a guaranteed fallback action.
:::

# Part 4: Nested `if` Statements

## What is Nesting?

::: {style="text-align:center; margin-top: 30px;"}
### A **nested `if`** is an `if` statement placed **inside** another `if` statement {style="color: #2980b9; font-size: 1.4em;"}
:::

**Real-life example:**

- If you have a ticket:
  - If your seat is in row A ‚Üí go to the front
  - Else ‚Üí go to the back
- Else ‚Üí you cannot enter

```python
has_ticket = True
seat_row = "A"

if has_ticket:
    print("Welcome!")
    if seat_row == "A":
        print("Please go to the front section.")
    else:
        print("Please go to the back section.")
else:
    print("Sorry, no ticket ‚Äî cannot enter.")
```

::: {.callout-important}
## üéØ Key Idea
The inner `if` only runs if the outer `if` condition is True first.
:::

## Syntax of Nested if

```python
if outer_condition:
    # outer block
    if inner_condition:
        # inner block (indented deeper)
        inner_code
    else:
        # inner else block
        inner_else_code
else:
    outer_else_code
```

**Each level of nesting = 4 more spaces of indentation:**

```python
age = 20
has_id = True

if age >= 18:
    print("Age is valid.")      # 4 spaces
    if has_id:
        print("ID confirmed.")  # 8 spaces
        print("Access granted!")
    else:
        print("No ID found. Cannot enter.")
else:
    print("Too young. Access denied.")
```

## Nested if ‚Äî Step by Step

```python
username = "admin"
password = "secret123"

if username == "admin":
    print("Username correct.")
    if password == "secret123":
        print("Password correct.")
        print("‚úÖ Login successful! Welcome, Admin.")
    else:
        print("‚ùå Wrong password.")
else:
    print("‚ùå Username not found.")
```

**Trace through different combinations:**

| username | password | Output |
|----------|----------|--------|
| `"admin"` | `"secret123"` | Login successful |
| `"admin"` | `"wrong"` | Wrong password |
| `"user"` | `"secret123"` | Username not found |
| `"user"` | `"wrong"` | Username not found |

## Caution: Don't Over-Nest!

Too much nesting makes code hard to read:

```python
# ‚ùå Hard to read ‚Äî too deeply nested
if condition1:
    if condition2:
        if condition3:
            if condition4:
                print("Finally!")

# ‚úÖ Better ‚Äî use and to combine conditions
if condition1 and condition2 and condition3 and condition4:
    print("Finally!")
```

::: {.callout-tip}
## üí° Rule of Thumb
Try not to nest more than 2‚Äì3 levels deep. Use `and` / `or` to flatten your logic when possible.
:::

# Part 5: Combining Conditions

## Recap: Logical Operators with if

From last class, we know `and`, `or`, `not`. Now we use them powerfully inside `if` statements:

```python
age = 25
income = 3000

# AND: both must be True
if age >= 18 and income >= 1000:
    print("You qualify for the loan.")

# OR: at least one must be True
if age < 18 or income < 500:
    print("You do not qualify.")

# NOT: reverse the condition
is_banned = False
if not is_banned:
    print("You may access the system.")
```

::: {.callout-tip}
## üí° Natural language mapping
"If age is at least 18 **and** income is at least 1000" ‚Üí `age >= 18 and income >= 1000`
:::

## Using `and` in if Statements

**Both conditions must be True for the block to run:**

```python
username = input("Username: ")
password = input("Password: ")

if username == "admin" and password == "1234":
    print("‚úÖ Login successful!")
else:
    print("‚ùå Invalid credentials.")
```

**Range checking with `and`:**

```python
temperature = float(input("Enter temperature (¬∞C): "))

if temperature >= 20 and temperature <= 35:
    print("üå§Ô∏è Comfortable weather for outdoor activities.")
elif temperature < 20:

else:
    print("üå°Ô∏è It is very hot. Stay in the shade!")
```

## Using `or` in if Statements

**At least one condition must be True:**

```python
day = input("Enter today's day: ").capitalize()

if day == "Saturday" or day == "Sunday":
    print("üéâ It's the weekend! No school today.")
else:

```

**Another example:**

```python
fruit = input("Enter a fruit: ").lower()

if fruit == "apple" or fruit == "pear" or fruit == "cherry":

elif fruit == "mango" or fruit == "banana":
```

## Using `not` in if Statements

**Reverse a condition:**

```python
is_logged_in = False

if not is_logged_in:
    print("Please log in to continue.")
else:
    print("Welcome back!")
```

**Practical use:**

```python
username = input("Enter username: ")

if username not in banned_users:

else:
```

::: {.callout-note}
## üí° `not in` operator
`x not in list` is the opposite of `x in list`. Very readable and natural!
:::

## Complex Conditions ‚Äî Parentheses Matter!

```python
age = 17
has_parent = True
has_id = False

# With parentheses ‚Äî clear logic
if age >= 18 or (age >= 15 and has_parent):
    print("You may enter.")
else:
    print("Entry not allowed.")

# Without parentheses ‚Äî confusing!
# Python evaluates 'and' before 'or', but add parentheses to be explicit
```

::: {.callout-warning}
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Precedence Reminder
`not` ‚Üí `and` ‚Üí `or` (same as we learned last class!)
**Always use parentheses** when mixing `and` and `or` to make your intent clear.
:::

# Part 6: Inline if (Ternary Expression)

## Shorthand if...else

For simple one-line decisions, Python has a compact syntax:

```python
# Normal if...else
age = 20
if age >= 18:
    status = "adult"
else:
    status = "minor"

# Equivalent Ternary / Inline if
status = "adult" if age >= 18 else "minor"

print(status)   # adult
```

**Syntax:**
```python
value = result_if_true if condition else result_if_false
```

::: {.callout-note}
## üí° When to use it
Use the ternary form when the choice is simple and fits on one readable line.
For complex logic, always use a full if...else for clarity.
:::

## Ternary Examples

```python
# Example 1: Pass/Fail label
score = 73
result = "Pass" if score >= 50 else "Fail"
print(f"Result: {result}")          # Pass

# Example 2: Absolute value
num = -15
absolute = num if num >= 0 else -num
print(f"Absolute value: {absolute}")  # 15

# Example 3: Max of two numbers
a, b = 10, 25
maximum = a if a > b else b
print(f"Maximum: {maximum}")         # 25

# Example 4: Greeting
hour = 14
greeting = "Good morning" if hour < 12 else "Good afternoon"
print(greeting)                      # Good afternoon
```

```python
larger = x if x > y else y
print(f"The larger number is: {larger}")
```

## Final Challenge ‚Äî Number Analysis Tool

**Combine everything you've learned:**

```python
print("=== Number Analyzer ===")
num = float(input("Enter any number: "))

# Check zero
if num == 0:
    print("The number is ZERO.")
else:
    # Check positive or negative
    if num > 0:
        print(f"{num} is POSITIVE.")
    else:
        print(f"{num} is NEGATIVE.")

    # Only check even/odd for whole numbers
    if num == int(num):
        num_int = int(num)
        parity = "EVEN" if num_int % 2 == 0 else "ODD"
        print(f"It is an {parity} integer.")

        # Check if divisible by 3 and 5
        if num_int % 3 == 0 and num_int % 5 == 0:
            print("Divisible by both 3 and 5 (FizzBuzz!).")
        elif num_int % 3 == 0:
            print("Divisible by 3.")
        elif num_int % 5 == 0:
            print("Divisible by 5.")

        # Range classification
        abs_num = abs(num_int)
        if abs_num < 10:
            size = "single-digit"
        elif abs_num < 100:
            size = "two-digit"
        elif abs_num < 1000:
            size = "three-digit"
        else:
            size = "large (1000+)"
        print(f"It is a {size} number.")
    else:
        print("It is a DECIMAL (float) number.")
```

## Summary: if, elif, else

**What you've learned today:**

| Concept | Purpose | Syntax |
|---------|---------|--------|
| `if` | Run code only when True | `if condition:` |
| `else` | Run code when `if` is False | `else:` |
| `elif` | Check additional conditions | `elif condition:` |
| Nested `if` | Decisions within decisions | Indent deeper |
| Combined conditions | `and`, `or`, `not` | `if a and b:` |
| Ternary | One-line shorthand | `x if cond else y` |

::: {.callout-important}
## üéØ Key Takeaways
- Python reads conditions **top to bottom** and stops at the **first True**
- Indentation is **mandatory** ‚Äî 4 spaces per level
- Use `elif` (not multiple `if`) when choices are mutually exclusive
- Use parentheses to make complex conditions clear
- Test all your **boundary values** (the exact cutoff numbers)!
:::

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

```python
# ‚ùå Mistake 1: Using = instead of ==
if age = 18:           # SyntaxError!
if age == 18:          # ‚úÖ Correct

# ‚ùå Mistake 2: Missing colon
if age >= 18           # SyntaxError!
if age >= 18:          # ‚úÖ Correct

# ‚ùå Mistake 3: Wrong indentation
if age >= 18:
print("Adult")         # IndentationError!
if age >= 18:
    print("Adult")     # ‚úÖ Correct

# ‚ùå Mistake 4: elif without if
elif score >= 80:      # SyntaxError! (no if before it)

# ‚ùå Mistake 5: else with a condition
else score < 50:       # SyntaxError! else has no condition
else:                  # ‚úÖ Correct
```

## Quick Reference Card

```python

if condition:
    code

# Structure 2: if...else
if condition:
    code_A
else:
    code_B

# Structure 3: if...elif...else
if condition1:
    code_A
elif condition2:
    code_B
elif condition3:
    code_C
else:
    code_D

# Structure 4: Nested
if outer:
    if inner:
        code_A
    else:
        code_B

# Structure 5: Ternary
result = value_A if condition else value_B
```
